2. A 3-month-old male infant is referred to the neurology clinic due to ongoing seizures and poor feeding. He was born after an uncomplicated pregnancy but has failed to gain weight adequately and has exhibited generalized hypotonia since birth. The parents note intermittent episodes of eye deviation and erratic limb movements. Physical examination reveals prominent upper limb spasticity, microcephaly, and absence of purposeful movements. EEG shows multifocal epileptiform discharges suggesting early-onset epilepsy. Brain MRI highlights a markedly simplified cortical pattern with broad gyri consistent with agyria-pachygyria typical of lissencephaly. Genetic analysis demonstrates a pathogenic variant in the ARX gene, confirming the diagnosis of X-linked lissencephaly 1. Supportive care is initiated focusing on seizure management and nutritional support, with genetic counseling offered to the family.
